title-group.article-title: Study on characteristics of printed circuit board liberation and its crushed products

contrib-group.aff: School of Environmental Science and Technology, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, P. R. China

author-notes.corresp: Aimin Li, School of Environmental Science and Technology, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, P. R. China Email: leeam@dlut.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue: Waste electrical and electronic equipment

abstract.p: Recycling printed circuit board waste (PCBW) waste is a hot issue of environmental protection and resource recycling. Mechanical and thermo-chemical methods are two traditional recycling processes for PCBW. In the present research, a two-step crushing process combined with a coarse-crushing step and a fine-pulverizing step was adopted, and then the crushed products were classified into seven different fractions with a standard sieve. The liberation situation and particle shape in different size fractions were observed. Properties of different size fractions, such as heating value, thermogravimetric, proximate, ultimate and chemical analysis were determined. The Rosin-Rammler model was applied to analyze the particle size distribution of crushed material. The results indicated that complete liberation of metals from the PCBW was achieved at a size less than 0.59 mm, but the nonmetal particle in the smaller-than-0.15 mm fraction is liable to aggregate. Copper was the most prominent metal in PCBW and mainly enriched in the 0.42–0.25 mm particle size. The Rosin-Rammler equation adequately fit particle size distribution data of crushed PCBW with a correlation coefficient of 0.9810. The results of heating value and proximate analysis revealed that the PCBW had a low heating value and high ash content. The combustion and pyrolysis process of PCBW was different and there was an obvious oxidation peak of Cu in combustion runs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The amount of waste electric and electronic equipment (WEEE) is increasing rapidly. As printed circuit board waste (PCBW) are an essential part of almost all electric and electronic equipment, the increase in the generation of WEEE leads to an increase in the amount of printed circuit board waste (PCBW). Printed circuit boards can be classified according to the material used in its substrate, for example if it is paper-based (FR-1, FR-2, XPC), composite material-based or fiberglass-based (FR-4) printed circuit board, and so on. Recycling of PCBW is a challenge because of the fact that PCBW are diverse and complex in terms of the type, size and shape of materials and components. Many studies have been carried out with regard to the recycling of PCBW with a view to recovering resources and, at the same time, preventing environmental contamination (Flandinet et al., 2012; Hall and Williams, 2007a,b; Mou et al., 2004; Park and Fray, 2009; Wang et al., 2005; Xiang et al., 2010; Xiu and Zhang, 2010; Yu et al., 2009). Mechanical and thermo-chemical methods are two traditional methods of recycling PCBW. For the mechanical process, liberation is the first step before separation can occur. After the liberation of the component materials, metallic concentrates are recovered through various mechanical processes, such as screening, specific gravity separation, magnetic separation, eddy current separation and electrostatic separation (Eswaraiah et al., 2008; Guo et al., 2011 ; Kumar et al., 2010; Li et al., 2007b; Murugan et al., 2008; ). Particle size, shape and liberation degree play crucial roles in the mechanical recycling process. The liberation of metals and nonmetals is usually obtained by sequential particle size reduction being done in a crusher machine. Crushing is obviously the core process in mechanical treatment and the process of crushing may directly affect the efficiency of subsequent separation steps, which then can affect the recovery rate and the purity of the metal. The thermo-chemical process usually includes pyrolysis, thermometallurgy and combustion. Among them, pyrolysis can be considered as an alternative method for recycling PCBW because when pyrolysis is applied to PCBW the organic resin should decompose to form an oil and gas that can be subsequently used for chemical feedstock or fuel. Furthermore, the baseplate of PCBW after pyrolysis are very friable and prone to delamination, making the process of separating the organic, metallic and glass fiber fractions of PCBW much easier, and, therefore, making recycling of each PCBW fraction more viable. A number of studies on the pyrolysis of PCBW have been reported (Barontini et al., 2005; Guan et al., 2008; Hall and Williams, 2007a,b; Long et al., 2010; Quan et al., 2010). In this aspect, a detailed knowledge of chemical and thermal degradation characteristics of PCBW which is very significant for both the design and the operation of PCBW thermal treatment facilities, is of great importance. However, dioxins and furan gases evolved from the pyrolysis process might induce environmental risk and should be considered in detail.

In the present investigation, characteristics of PCBW liberation and its crushed products were studied. First, the PCBW was pulverized in a process consisting of a coarse-crushing step and a fine-pulverizing step using a shearing machine and a hammer grinder together. A standard sieve is applied to screen crushed material to different size fractions. Characterization of different size fractions from the sieving operation was carried out using various methods of analysis, such as liberation degree analysis, size distribution analysis, elemental composition analysis, proximate analysis, heat value analysis and thermogravimetric analysis. These data could be used in the recycling process design and energy recovery of PCBW.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: PCBW feedstock without electronic elements was obtained from a local printed circuit board factory in Dalian city. The baseplates of the PCBW consisted of a woven fiberglass mat impregnated with thermoset resins with copper coating on the baseplates. The samples were cut into small pieces of about 1 cm × 1 cm by pliers before being subjected to crushing machines.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: PCBW contains copper foil and are enforced by glass-fiber, so intensity, tenacity and rigidity are very high, making them hard to crush. In this study, a two-step crushing process was adopted. A CSJ-80B dust absorption crusher (Jiangyin Xinda Machinery Co., Ltd, Jiangyin, China), as shown in Figure 1(a), was used as crude crusher. The crusher consisted mainly of a feeder, crushing chamber, output collector, electromotor and dust bag. The PCBW sample was fed into the crusher manually. The internal structure of the crushing chamber is presented in the top right of Figure 1(a). The crusher was driven by a three-phase AC induction motor at a fixed speed of 400 rpm, which was connected to the crusher by a triangular belt. The rated power of the motor was 1.5 kW. When the samples passed through the crushing chamber, the blades on rotor and stator throw intensive impact and shearing forces to the PCBW samples, which break them up into small pieces. The crushed PCBW was collected in output collector and the dust produced during crushing process was collected in a dust bag. A WF-18B dust absorption mill (Jiangyin Xinda Machinery), as shown in Figure 1(b) was employed as the second crusher. The internal structure of the milling chamber is presented in the top right of the Figure 1(b). The mill was driven by a three-phase AC induction motor at a fixed speed of 5200 rpm, and the rated power of the motor was 2.2 kW. When the sample passed through the milling chamber, the intensive force caused by relative movement between the active of fluted disc and fixed fluted disc makes the PCBW samples break up into a small powder. After crushing and milling, the product was then subjected to size analysis by sieving. A standard vibrating screen (BD-300, Beijing Boda Machinery Co., Ltd, Beijing, China), as displayed in Figure 1(c) was used to screen the milled materials; all materials after screening were weighed. The milled products were classified into seven different fractions: <0.15 mm, 0.15–0.18 mm, 0.18–0.25 mm, 0.25–0.42 mm, 0.42–0.59 mm, 0.59–0.84 mm and >0.84 mm.

caption.p: Experimental equipment used in our studies: (a) crude crusher, (b) second crusher and (c) vibrating screen.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: The dissociation situation and morphology of PCBW after crushing were observed by a digital camera (Olympus 565uz, Tokyo, Japan) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM; JEOL JSM-5600LV, Tokyo, Japan). The fractions larger than 0.42 mm were observed by digital camera and the fractions smaller than 0.42 mm were observed by SEM.

In order to homogenize the sample for later elemental composition analysis, proximate analysis, calorific value analysis and thermogravimetric analysis, the coarser fractions (0.25–0.42 mm, 0.42–0.5 9 mm, 0.59–0.84 mm and >0.84 mm) were first ground to a fine powder with a grinder (Retsch, ZM 200, Haan, Germany) separately and then each fraction was mixed uniformly by shaking. The analytical specimen of each fraction was taken using the quadrant sampling method. To verify the validity of the data, all experiments were performed twice and average values were listed.

The hydrogen (H), carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) content of PCBW samples in different size fractions was determined on a VarioEL III Elemental Analyzer, Elementar corporation, Hanau, Germany, and other elemental compositions were determined via X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometers (XRF-1800, Shimadzu, Tokyo, Japan) which carried out qualitative analysis of elements from beryllium (Be) to uranium (U). Absolute errors of the analysis results conducted by the elemental analyzer and XRF were ≤0.1%.

The calorific values of PCBW samples in different size fractions were determined by burning a weighed sample in an oxygen bomb calorimeter (Hebi HongTai Electronic technology Co., Ltd, Hebi, China). The errors of heating values obtained in this study were about 1–2%. First, standard benzoic acid (C6H6COOH) was used to obtained the water equivalent of the calorimeter and then, according to the temperature rise of the calorimeter before and after the sample ignited, the calorific values of sample could be calculated by following equation (1):

where Q is heat of combustion of the sample, MJ/kg; ΔT is corrected temperature rise, °C; K is water equivalent of calorimeter, MJ/°C; e is correction for heat of combustion of firing wire, MJ; m is mass of the PCBW sample, g.

Ash content (Ad), moisture content (Md), volatile matter (Vd) and fixed carbon (FC) are considered as proximate analysis and they were conducted on a SDTGA5000 automatic proximate analyzer (Hunan Sundy Technology Development Industrial Co., Ltd, Changsha, China). The errors of proximate analysis were about 1%.

Thermal degradation of the milled PCBW samples was performed on a EXSTAR TG/DTA6300 Thermobalance at different atmospheres: nitrogen for the pyrolysis run and air for the combustion run. The sensitivity of the thermobalance was 1 µg. For each run, approximately 10 mg of sample was heated from room temperature to 800°C at 20°C/min with a flow rate of 200 ml/min. Thermogravimetry (TG) and differential thermogravimetry (DTG) curves were recorded continuously and presented as percentages of initial sample weight.

sec.title: Characteristics analysis of dissociation
sec.p: Preceding physical and mechanical method, good liberation is the premise to further separation. The optimal crushing result is that each component in PCBW powders achieves monomer dissociation. In the present article, the degree of liberation was introduced to describe the dissociation situation of copper in milled PCBW, which can be expressed as equation (2) (Zhang and Forssberg, 1999):

in which LD denotes the liberation degree of copper; Nf indicates the number of copper monomer particle; and Nl indicates the number of intergrowth particles of copper and nonmetals. According to equation (2), the degree of liberation of copper at a certain size fraction could be determined by counting.

Through observing the crushed material by digital camera, the dissociation situation of PCBW after crushing can be initially determined. It could be seen from the photographs that, when particle size was larger than 0.84 mm (as presented in Figure 2a), metals and nonmetals in PCBW were undissociated. In the size range 0.84–0.59 mm, metals began to strip from baseplates (see Figure 2(b), indicated by arrows A and B), but there were still some intergrowth particles of copper and nonmetals, as indicated by arrow C in Figure 2a. In the size range 0.59–0.42 mm, metals achieved approximately complete liberation, which is in agreement with the experimental results found by Guo et al. (2011) and Li et al. (2007a). As shown by arrow D in Figure 2c, the liberated metals included granular, rod-like copper.

caption.p: Digital photographs of milled printed circuit boards. (a) >0.84 mm, (b) 0.84–0.59 mm, (c) 0.59–0.42 mm.

sec.p: The main components of the nonmetals in PCBW are thermoset resins and reinforcing materials. The shape and composition of nonmetals varied with particle size as seen through careful observation on SEM, as indicated in Figure 3. Particles in the size range 0.42–0.25 mm were present mainly as irregularly-shaped granules, with the majority of the glass fiber surface being encapsulated in epoxy resin (Figure 3a). The 0.25–0.18 mm fractions contained predominantly fiber-particulate bundles. The thermosetting resin got stuck inside the glass fibers, forming a large fiber-particulate bundle of loosely entangled fibers. Particles sized 0.18–0.15 mm contained both fiber bundles and single fibers, as shown in Figure 3c. One part of the single fiber marked by the circle is enlarged in the top right of Figure 3c. It is clearly seen that the fibers have a rough surface with a small quantity of resin. Fractions shorter than 0.15 mm, where the glass fibers are largely separated from the thermoset resin, were mainly in the form of single fibers and resin powder, as shown in Figure 3d. Most of the single fibers in these fractions were of short length.

caption.p: Scanning electron microscope (SEM) micrographs of milled printed circuit boards with different particle sizes. (a) 0.42–0.25 mm, (b) 0.25–0.18 mm, (c) 0.18–0.15 mm, (d) <0.15 mm.

sec.p: PCBWs are heterogeneous samples, which usually contains glass fiber, reinforced resin and metals. The difference in shape and composition among crushed particles with different particle sizes could be determined by the intrinsic structure of PCBW and the two-step crushing process. Thin copper foils are attached to epoxy resin plates reinforced on each side by glass fibers; they become smaller as a result of simultaneous tearing when these brittle PCBW components are milled. Copper is easy to deform and hard to break under loads; as the size is reduced it might strip from the baseplates of PCBW. However, glass fiber and resin in raw material presented a stronger combination and most glass fiber surfaces were encapsulated by resin. The liberation of the resin from the glass fiber surface would leads to the formation of a large fiber-particulate bundle of loosely entangled fibers (Figure 3b). As the resin inside the glass fiber is liberated, the formed fiber bundle becomes single fibers (Figure 3c). These liberated single glass fibers are expected to be brittle; as the size reduced further, they were cut short and dispersed within the thermoset resin granules (Figure 3d).

sec.title: Size distribution of the crushed products
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the size distribution of PCBW after crushing. Materials in the complete dissociation sample (<0.59 mm) were found to compose >82.53% of the total particle weight. The weight percentage of particles <0.15 mm constituted the largest portion, amounting to 37.15% of the total particle weight. However, too fine a size—which insures absolute metal/non-metal separation—may not be desired from an energetic perspective owing to the excessive energy required for size reduction. Additionally, based on visual observation, nonmetal particles in the fraction sized <0.15mm is fine and liable to aggregate as presented in Figure 5, leading to inefficient separation (Wu et al., 2009). Thus, the optimum particle size for mechanical dissociation of metals and nonmetals in PCBW should be controlled in the range of 0.15–0.59 mm. In order to avoid excessive fine generation and enhance the degree of liberation, some researchers carried out a study on cryogenic comminution and wet crushing of PCBW (Tan et al., 2011; Zou et al., 2006).

caption.p: Mass distribution of printed circuit board waste after crushing.
Aggregate of nonmetal powder in <0.15 mm fraction.

sec.title: Mathematical models of particle size distribution
sec.p: Particle size distribution (PSD) is probably the most important physical characteristic of solids. Many distribution functions have been proposed to characterize the fraction of materials as a function of the particle size (González-Tello et al., 2008; Macías-García et al., 2004). The Rosin–Rammler distribution function has long been used to describe the particle size distribution of powders of various types and sizes. The function is particularly suited to represent powders made by grinding, milling and crushing operations. The governing equation for the Rosin–Rammler particle size distribution may be expressed as shown in equation (3) (Rosin and Rammler, 1933):

where R(x) is cumulative oversize mass, %; x is particle size, assumed to be equivalent to nominal sieve aperture size, mm; n is the size parameter or Rosin–Rammler geometric mean diameter, mm; and b is distribution parameter or Rosin–Rammler skewness parameter (dimensionless). A small b indicates a wide spread in PSD. The Rosin–Rammler function was linearized as shown in equation (4):

where n is the slope and lnb is the intercept. Often, a least-square regression analysis is used to fit a line to the data point. Figure 6 shows the fits of experimental data to the Rosin–Rammler model. The correlation coefficient, R2, was 0.9810. The closer R2 is to 1 the better the fit of the experimental results to the model.

caption.p: Results of least-squares regression analysis of particle size distribution (PSD) fitting to the experimental data.

sec.p: After calculation, the values of b and n were found to be 2.585 and 0.846 respectively. The resulting distribution model for milled PCBW obtained by application of the Rosin–Rammler model was given by the equation (5):

Figure 7 showed the cumulative oversized product data and its fitting curves. From Figure 7 it was deduced that the Rosin–Rammler model provided a good fit to the experimental PSD curve. As the speed of the mill used in our experiment has only a fixed value of 5200 rpm, and its speed can not be adjusted, we did not present the effect of grinding parameters in this article. However, the parameters of Rosin-Rammler model obtained at different grinding speeds have been reported by Zhao et al. (2009). Their results revealed that the values for both n and b increased with an increase in grinding speed.

caption.p: Cumulative oversized product data and fitting curves.

sec.title: Elemental composition analysis
sec.p: The C, H and N content in each fraction of milled PCBW determined by the elemental analyzer is presented in Figure 8a and the contents of other elemental compositions determined by XRF are shown in Figure 8b. The element composition analysis results conducted on the elemental analyzer and by XRF revealed that there was a total of about 21 elements in the PCBW. The major nonmetallic elements included H, C, oxygen (O), silicon (Si) and bromine (Br). The dominant metallic elements in PCBW included magnesium (Mg), aluminium (Al), calcium(Ca), iron (Fe), copper (Cu) and barium (Ba). A high content of Cu compared with the other metallic elements studied was observed. The concentrations of copper reached a maximum in the 0.42–0.25 mm size fraction—about 32.32%. Aside from the special case of precious metals, copper in PCBW is, economically-speaking, the most interesting metal for recovery and could be used as a secondary raw material because of its relatively high content compared with the corresponding content in explorable ores and its economic value. In addition, PCBW contained environmentally-harmful materials, such as chromium (Cr) and Br, which need to be recovered or removed before disposal.

caption.p: Elemental compositions in each fraction of milled printed circuit board analyzed by (a) the elemental analyzer and (b) X-ray fluorescence (XRF).

sec.title: Heating value and proximate analyses
sec.p: Calorific value—the amount of energy released by each unit of combustible mass—is the most important property of a sample which determines the energy value of it. Direct combustion with energy recovery for PCBW waste is usually hindered by Br content and the need to prevent the formation of brominated dioxins; however, it is necessary to know the calorific value of PCBW as this value is usually used for the energy balance calculation during the pyrolysis process. The results of heating value and proximate analysis of each fraction in milled PCBW are given in Table 1. The volatile matter was related to the organic matter in PCBW and the ash usually consisted of metal, glass fiber and other refractory oxides. It can be seen from Table 1 that the moisture content of the samples was between 0.34% and 0.85%, the ash content ranged from 53.87% in 0.18–0.15 mm fractions to 80.45% in the 0.42–0.25 mm fractions, the volatile matter content was in the range of 22.84% in the 0.59–0.42 mm particle size fractions and 39.62% in the 0.18–0.15 mm fractions, and the fixed carbon content varied between 0.16% in the 0.84–0.59-mm fractions and 7.92% in particle size fractions <0.15 mm. The calorific values of the samples changed in the range of 8.07–11.69 MJ/kg. As can be seen from Table 1, the proximate analysis and heating value of the milled PCBW samples varies over a broad range. PCBW samples had a low heating value and high ash content.

caption.p: Proximate analysis results and heating value of printed circuit board samples

fn.p: Md, moisture content; Vd, volatile matter; Ad, ash content; FC, fixed carbon.

sec.title: Thermal-chemical property analysis
sec.p: The thermal stability of the non-metallic fractions is very important, both for the physical and chemical recycling methods (Guo et al., 2009). The thermal behaviors of milled PCBW in the fractions of 0.59–0.42 mm, 0.42–0.25 mm and 0.25–0.18 mm were analyzed as a reference in this study. The corresponding TG and DTG curves for pyrolysis and combustion are presented in Figure 9a, b. As can be seen, there is little difference on the thermal stability of fractions with different sizes. The pyrolysis of PCBW only included one major step and DTG curves exhibited a single peak. Decomposition occurred mainly in the range of 299–391°C. The different behavior of the thermal decomposition in combustion runs can be observed. Senneca et al. (2002) considered that two extreme pathways of solid fuel conversion in an oxidizing atmosphere are possible, as shown in Figure 10. One is represented by the sequential steps of purely thermal degradation of the material (pyrolysis; reaction A ) followed by combustion of volatile matter and char generated by pyrolysis (reaction B).

caption.p: Thermogravimetry (TG) and differential TG (DTG) curves during pyrolysis (a) and combustion (b) of milled PCBW in particle size fractions of 0.59–0.42 mm, 0.42–0.25 mm and 0.25–0.18 mm.
The possible pathways of solid fuel conversion in an oxidizing atmosphere.

sec.p: According to Senneca et al. (2002), there is a clear behavior of the type of pyrolytic decomposition with char formation and char combustion for PCBW combustion. However, an interesting phenomenon was observed in the combustion curve in that the weight increased with the temperature. The combustion behavior of pure copper appeared as a similar weight increase peak (as indicated in Figure 9b). This could be due to the interaction of oxygen with copper to form Cu-O and Cu-(O)-Cu species in the solid residues, in accordance with results reported by Chien et al. (2000).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The performed investigations showed that two-step crushing was an effective process in completely stripping metals from the baseplates of PCBW. PCBW could be fully dissociated between metal and nonmetals when particle size was <0.59 mm. Material in the complete dissociation sample was found to constitute >82.53% of the total particle weight. There are many kinds of metals in PCBW, such as Mg, Al, Ca, Fe, Cu and Ba. Among them, Cu is the primary metal and it mainly enriched in the 0.42–0.25 mm particle size fraction. The mathematical model of particle size distribution for crushing PCBW was in the form of R(x)=100 exp(−2.585x0.846). The proximate analysis and heating value of the milled PCBW samples in each fraction were different. The calorific values of the samples changed in the range of 8.07 to 11.69 MJ/kg. The combustion and pyrolysis processes of milled PCBW are different. The pyrolysis of PCBW only included one major step. In combustion runs, owing to the interaction of O with Cu to form Cu-O and Cu-(O)-Cu species in the solid residues, there was an increase in weight with temperature in the combustion curve of PCBW.
